query: What are the observed effects of using chemical or plant-based attractants to enhance natural enemy populations?
relevant_summary: Studies have documented varied effects of using chemical or plant-based attractants to enhance natural enemy populations. For plant-based attractants, four studies from China, Germany, India and Kenya found that growing non-crop plants that produce chemicals attractive to natural enemies resulted in higher numbers of natural enemies in three studies, while one study found no effect on parasitism when the plant used was not found to be attractive to natural enemies in lab studies (Action 724). All four studies found decreased pest populations or pest damage, and one replicated, randomised, controlled study found increased crop yield (Action 724). Push-pull systems using trap and repellent crops showed that two randomised, replicated, controlled studies from Kenya found increased parasitism of stem borer larvae, and studies from Kenya and South Africa found more natural predators in push-pull systems (Action 753). For chemical attractants, one review and two of five studies from Asia, Europe and North America found that attractive chemicals increased parasitism, while two studies found greater parasitism for some but not all chemicals, crops, sites or years, and one study found no effect (Action 754). Five of 13 studies found more natural enemies while eight found positive effects that varied between enemy groups, sites or study dates (Action 754). Regarding pest control, three of nine studies found fewer pests, although the effect occurred only in the egg stage in one study, while two studies found more pests and four found no effect (Action 754). For flower plantings, three replicated studies from Italy and the USA found greater pest reduction or higher proportions of parasitized pests in fields with planted flower strips, and multiple studies found more natural enemies in fields with planted flower strips compared to fields without them (Action 1400). However, some studies also found inconsistent effects, with one study finding more damage by caterpillars in tomatoes next to planted flower strips and another finding more pests on tomatoes next to planted flower strips (Action 1400).

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "1400",
  "action_title": "Pest regulation: Plant flowers",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
Pest regulation (3 studies): Three replicated studies from Italy and the USA found greater pest reduction or higher proportions of parasitized pests in fields and farms with planted flower strips.
Crop damage (2 studies): One replicated, randomized, controlled study from Italy found more damage by caterpillars, but not by aphids, in tomatoes next to planted flower strips, compared to tomatoes next to bare ground. One replicated, paired, controlled study from Italy found that planted flower strips had inconsistent effects on crop damage by pests.
Pest numbers (2 studies): One replicated, paired, controlled study from Italy found more pests on tomatoes next to planted flower strips, compared to tomatoes next to unplanted field margins. One replicated before-and-after study from the USA found more aphids in fields after flower strips were made available.
Natural enemy numbers (4 studies): Two replicated studies from the USA found more natural enemies in fields with planted flower strips, compared to fields without planted flower strips, in some comparisons. Two replicated, controlled studies from Italy found more natural enemies in planted flower strips than on bare ground, and one of these studies also found more species of natural enemies.
Implementation options (4 studies): Two replicated, controlled studies from the USA and Spain found that some flower species were more attractive to natural enemies than others. Two replicated, controlled studies from Italy found that planting more species of flowers, compared to fewer, had inconsistent effects on pests and pest species, but one of these found less crop damage next to flower strips with more species, compared to fewer, in some comparisons. This study also found more species of natural enemies in flower strips, over time, but did not find more individuals."
}

tools_called.args: {"query_string": "attractant natural enemies effectiveness parasitism biological control", "k": 10}

query: When altering the timing of chemical applications for pest control, what are the comparative effects of delaying herbicide use versus changing insecticide timing?
relevant_summary: Delaying herbicide use results in mixed effects on pest control systems. According to action 774, delaying herbicide treatments increased natural enemies in two studies from Australia and Denmark, though benefits varied by natural enemy group and were less pronounced early in the season. However, delaying herbicides led to increased weed pressure and had mixed effects on insect pests, with one study finding more insect pests for some groups while another found fewer pests in specific experiments and crop varieties. Crop damage was reduced in some but not all varieties and study years, while yields either decreased or showed no effect. In contrast, altering insecticide timing shows different patterns. Action 723 indicates that applying insecticides earlier rather than later in the growing season increased natural enemies in one UK study. Early insecticide application reduced pests or disease damage in two of four studies, though effects varied with insecticide type, while two studies found no effect on pests or damage. Yield effects were mixed when insecticides were applied early, with one study finding higher yields when applications were timed to periods of suspected crop susceptibility. One study found higher profits and similar costs when insecticides were applied only during times of suspected crop susceptibility. The evidence suggests that both timing alterations affect natural enemies, pest control, and yields differently, with herbicide delays generally showing more consistent benefits for natural enemies but potential negative impacts on weed control and yields, while insecticide timing changes show more variable effects depending on application timing relative to crop growth stages.

query: What are the documented financial impacts, in terms of profit and costs, of implementing various natural pest control strategies?
relevant_summary:
Based on the documented action evidence, several natural pest control strategies show specific financial impacts:

Threshold-based pesticide spraying (Action 750) demonstrates significant cost savings with nine studies finding fewer pesticide applications were needed and three studies finding or predicting lower production costs. Two of three randomised, replicated, controlled studies found similar profits using threshold-based and conventional spraying regimes, with one study finding effects varied between sites and years.

Push-pull cropping systems (Action 753) show positive economic benefits, with two studies in Kenya and a review finding greater economic benefits. One study found higher production costs in the first year, but equal or lower costs in the following five years.

Beetle banks (Action 729) can provide economic savings, with one replicated, randomised, controlled trial and a review showing that beetle banks could make economic savings if they prevented pests from reaching a spray threshold or causing 5% yield loss.

Organic farming conversion (Action 717) presents mixed financial outcomes. One study found net profit increased if produce received a premium, but otherwise profit decreased. Another study found a negative or no effect on profit.

Alley cropping (Action 718) showed lower costs but also lower profit in alley cropped plots according to one study from the USA.

tools_called.args: {"query_string": "natural pest control financial costs profits economic impacts", "k": 10}
{"query_string": "biological pest control IPM integrated pest management economic cost benefit", "k": 10}

}

query: What actions are available to control weeds specifically in pasture or grassland systems?
relevant_summary: Several actions are available to control weeds in pasture and grassland systems. Mixed pasture systems can reduce weeds, as two studies from the USA found reduced weeds in mixed compared to monoculture pasture (Action 721). Livestock grazing can be used to manage vegetation, with studies showing that introduction of livestock grazing increased the abundance of certain species and that sheep-grazed pasture was used more by feeding animals than ungrazed pasture (Action 2545). For specific weed control without damaging other plants, various methods are effective including cutting, infection with fungal pathogens, and lenient grazing for long-term control of creeping thistle, while grass-specific herbicide treatments can eliminate black grass and reduce grass diversity while increasing broadleaved plants (Action 123). Modifying grazing regimes in grassland and shrubland can affect vegetation management, with different grazing intensities showing various effects on plant and animal communities (Action 3490). Additionally, removing problematic vegetation can be effective for invasive species control in grassland areas (Action 432). Some studies also found that grazing herbivores on pasture instead of providing artificial foods can be beneficial for wildlife populations (Action 2398), and grassland restoration or creation can support various species while involving management practices like mowing and weeding or herbicide application (Action 3943).

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "2545",
  "action_title": "Manage vegetation using livestock grazing",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies evaluated the effects on mammals of managing vegetation using livestock grazing. Four studies were in the USA, one was in Norway and one was in Mexico.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Abundance (1 study): A replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that introduction of livestock grazing increased the abundance of Stephens’ kangaroo rat after two years.

BEHAVIOUR (5 STUDIES)

Use (4 studies): One of four studies (three replicated controlled studies and a before-and-after study), in the USA and Norway, found that sheep-grazed pasture was used by feeding reindeer more than was ungrazed pasture. One found mixed effects on Rocky Mountain elk use of grazed plots and another found no response of Rocky Mountain elk to spring cattle grazing. The forth study found cattle grazing to increase the proportion of rough fescue biomass utilized by elk in the first, but not second winter after grazing.
Behaviour change (1 study): A replicated, paired sites study in Mexico found that in pastures grazed by cattle, Tehuantepec jackrabbits spent more time feeding than they did in pastures not grazed by cattle."
}

{
  "action_id": "2398",
  "action_title": "Graze herbivores on pasture, instead of sustaining with artificial foods",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

One study evaluated the effects of grazing mammalian herbivores on pasture, instead of sustaining with artificial foods. This study was in South Africa.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Reproductive success (1 study): A site comparison study in South Africa found that a population of roan antelope grazed on pasture had a higher population growth rate than populations provided solely with imported feed.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

{
  "action_id": "3943",
  "action_title": "Restore or create grassland/savannas",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies evaluated the effects on butterflies and moths of restoring or creating grassland or savanna. Three studies were in the USA, two were in the UK, and one was in Italy.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Richness/diversity (1 study): One replicated, paired, site comparison study in Italy found that created semi-natural grasslands had a greater diversity of butterflies than adjacent conifer forests, but a lower diversity than species-rich pastures.

POPULATION RESPONSE (4 STUDIES)

Abundance (4 studies): Two site comparison studies (including one replicated, paired study) in Italy and the USA found that created semi-natural grasslands and restored grasslands and oak barrens had a higher abundance of butterflies and regal fritillaries than adjacent conifer forests, species-rich pastures or unmanaged or remnant prairies. One site comparison study in the USA found that prairies restored 5–10 years ago by seeding with native species, mowing, and weeding or applying herbicide, had a greater abundance of Fender’s blue eggs than a prairie restored 1–2 years ago, and a similar abundance to remnant prairies. One study in the USA reported that restored prairie supported a translocated population of regal fritillaries for at least three years after restoration.

BEHAVIOUR (3 STUDIES)

Use (2 studies): One of two replicated, before-and-after studies in the UK reported that following grassland restoration the area occupied by small pearl-bordered fritilliaries increased. The other study reported that following grassland restoration the number of marsh fritillary populations at each site remained the same or increased.
Behaviour change (1 study): One site comparison study in the USA found that Fender’s blue butterflies spent a similar proportion of time laying eggs in prairies restored 5–10 years ago by seeding with nectar species, mowing, and weeding or applying herbicide, and in remnant prairies."
}

{
  "action_id": "3490",
  "action_title": "Modify grazing regime: Grassland & shrubland",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Four studies evaluated the effects of modifying grazing regimes in grassland and shrubland on reptile populations. Three studies were in the USA and one was in Australia.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Richness/diversity (3 studies): One replicated site comparison study in the USA found that sites with different grazing intensities had similar reptile diversity. One replicated, site-comparison, paired sites study in Australia found no clear effects of modifying grazing intensities on reptile species richness. One replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that areas that were lightly grazed or unmanaged had lower reptile species richness than areas that were heavily grazed in combination with burning.

POPULATION RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Abundance (2 studies): One of two replicated studies (including one site comparison, paired sites study) in the USA and Australia found that plots with lighter grazing had higher lizard abundance than those with heavier grazing in four of five vegetation types. The other study found that the abundance of individual reptile species or species groups remained similar at different grazing intensities.
Survival (1 study): One site comparison study in the USA found that survival of Texas horned lizards was higher in moderately grazed than heavily grazed sites.

BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)

Use (1 study): One replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that light grazing or heavy grazing and burning had mixed effects on the reptile species that used those areas."
}
